Author: CHMEX#0686
Content: en.bitcoin.it/wiki/OP_RETURN

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: @webworker01 @CHMEX both are the same OP_RETURN

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: OP_RETURN is a special bitcoin script opcode that says "the rest of this script is just data, do not store it in the utxo database", which every node must store in memory

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: this service records things in OP_RETURN, very similar to how dpow uses OP_RETURN: https://opentimestamps.org/

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: in the days before OP_RETURN, people stored data as actual utxo vin/vouts

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: such as, the original Satoshi whitepaper PDF is stored directly as a multisig transaction(!)

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: that bloats the utxo DB for the rest of time on every node

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: hence why btc core is so against storing rando data as utxos, OP_RETURN allows rando data to not pollute utxo DB

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: opreturn script returns failed

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: so any attempt to spend it will fail

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: @webworker01 by definition, OP_RETURN outputs are not spendable (unspendable), and do not need to be stored in the utxo database. That is what he is trying to say, I think

Author: Deleted User#0000

Author: smellycouch#3071
Content: @Alright   thx

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: notary nodes would break anything that tried to log their transactions ... when the local wallet itself cant go a couple of days witout totally bogging down and breaking, an explorer could hope for at best a few weeks before having corrupted data.

Author: smellycouch#3071
Content: @blackjok3r  is that because of the number of transactions, or some other factor?      I'm interested.   that address above is at 1.2 million transactions.   Many systems need to handle that much per second, with near zero tolerance for error.   I do hope to see KMD itself handle that any transactions per second someday

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: Its a database issue, not the actual blockchain itself... the blockchain is accurate but when you try to keep track of the tranacions in some place (like the BTC wallet code, or the insight DB's (for explorers) It just doesnt work ... I figured out ways to "fix" it on the BTC wallet code side... where the node lives inside a "bubble" of 1000 blocks, and does not save its tranasacion history from before that time. This has 100% fixed any problem notary node has of bogging down, btu its a very specific fix and definatly cannot apply to all nodes. I think possibly a mining pool node's wallet could also use this method. Exchanges though, not very sure.

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: If some use was using a blockchain for millions of transacions, I think they would need to deploy thier own entrie DB code and infristrucure to support that.

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: No mean feat ... I looked at the BTC wallet code for about 3-4 days, to wrap my head around what would be required to replace it before deciding that it basically cant be done.

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: Decided on hacking workarounds into it instead. As unless your really pushing it to do what it was never designed ot do it does a perfecty fine job.

Author: smellycouch#3071
Content: @blackjok3r   thank you, very interesting.        I will save myself the 3-4 days then üòÉ      I'm surprised a DB can't handle it, but glad it's an external issue

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: Yeah not really sure why or how it ends up corrupted, this is pretty rare but a rescan on a wallet with millions of transactions takes an extreme amount of time.

Author: smellycouch#3071
Content: that it does üòâ  üçø

Author: Mylo#8306
Content:
i think it's something to do with moving wallet.dat files between block reward maturity.   just a guess.   the active wallet.dat on the notary nodes sometimes rescan from a particular height _after_ their block reward matures.

reason i think it's related to this is the pioneers NN wallet was -50 to -100KMD for a while.  side note, a rollover wallet sometimes tops up the NN wallet to do notarizations.  When these mature block rewards are accounted for but not spendable because they don't have `nLockTime` set.   <--- too low level for me to hand-on-heart say i'm an expert on behaviour without someone blessing my assumption with "yes you are correct mylo" or "derrr mylo, you are so wrong" üòÑ

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content: @dukeleto why is git clean less optimal?

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content: Isn't that the exact point of git clean?

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content: To get the repo in a clean state for doing a fresh build

Author: SHossain#0007
Content: best thing for me is `git reset --hard`. works all the time

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content:
`git clean` is like `git reset --hard` but nukes everything. 
`git reset --hard` can leave some bits behind like build artifacts

Author: SHossain#0007
Content: yes, and my own files

Author: SHossain#0007
Content: for removing old builds i use `make clean`

Author: SHossain#0007
Content: basically, i use these everyday

Author: Mylo#8306
Content: thx `git reset --hard` sounds like something i shd use more, cheers

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: @lukechilds it can lose data accidentally, mostly

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: the "less optimal" is that it can do what you want, but you *might* lose data, depending on the state of your tree

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: build.sh X 3 cannot lose your data

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content:
@SHossain i have this shell alias for like 10+ years: ```
$ type undo
undo is aliased to `git reset HEAD^'
```

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: not --hard tho, because that can lose data. Don't make it easy to accidentally lose data, is very core git philosophy

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: so Git folks veer towards the solution that has least risk of losing data, if multiple choices exist to do the same thing

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: `undo` is great for "oh, i didn't want that commit message, let's do that again"
